Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/scalar/guardwidening-cpp/#l00108">108</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/scalar/guardwidening-cpp">GuardWidening.cpp</a>.

### findInsertionPointForWideCondition() {#a0d69c80bfa592d9ac6901fa22f7ff405}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>static std::optional&lt; BasicBlock::iterator &gt; anonymous&#95;namespace&#123;GuardWidening.cpp&#125;::findInsertionPointForWideCondition (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; WCOrGuard)</>}
  labels = {["static"]}>
Find a point at which the widened condition of <code>Guard</code> should be inserted.

When it is represented as intrinsic call, we can do it right before the call instruction. However, when we are dealing with widenable branch, we must account for the following situation: widening should not turn a loop-invariant condition into a loop-variant. It means that if widenable.condition() call is invariant (w.r.t. any loop), the new wide condition should stay invariant. Otherwise there can be a miscompile, like the one described at <a href="https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/60234">https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/60234</a>. The safest way to do it is to expand the new condition at WC&#39;s block.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/scalar/guardwidening-cpp/#l00125">125</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/scalar/guardwidening-cpp">GuardWidening.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>
